Some countries do better than we do. It is always a bit higher at post-primary level and this reflects the range of subjects taught at that level. There are other elements of diversity. Children in classrooms today, and we have very diverse classrooms, are really not seeing themselves reflected in the teaching population. This is not to denigrate the high-quality teachers and what they do.
And the great work that they do. Is there an active plan on this?

It is something the workforce development plan will look at, with regard to how we increase diversity in the profession. Is it about providing different pathways for different people to enter? For example, we are looking at a tertiary pathway into teacher education.
The national tertiary council looks at further and higher education pathways, so that people who might not necessarily think teaching is something for them can do a year in a local ETB-----
Sorry, but this is really important. Why are there more male principals?
I suppose-----
It is 90% of teachers who are female.
I cannot tell the Senator why that is definitively, or what is behind it. There certainly are more male principals. They are not proportionate to the number of teachers.
Would Ms Conduit come back to me on that please?

I will continue in a similar vein in terms of who is going into teaching. I grew up on a council estate in Kells. I remember giving a lift to a few lads to a game of football. They talked about work and such and such a doctor, and one said to the other, "Your father has to be a doctor for you to be a doctor". Of course, they were men but there was the idea of this not happening in their area. It is about the issue of diversity but it is also about social class, including people in DEIS schools. Kids are coming out of DEIS primary schools into secondary. Katriona O'Sullivan has written well in relation to this. Is diversity, from a socioeconomic and socially disadvantaged perspective, something the Department is looking at in trying to see more teachers coming out of those areas?

I mentioned my wife so I might as well mention my brother, who is a teacher in Australia. He did his leaving certificate, went into construction and then did a teach for Australia programme, which seems to be based on a teach for America programme, which entails getting people from non-typical backgrounds into education. They then commit to teach in disadvantaged areas for a period. I am glad to hear Ms Conduit is interested in this. What is likely to happen in that area?

It is certainly something that is of huge interest. We see really successful initiatives. As the Deputy is probably aware, Katriona O'Sullivan benefited from the Trinity access programme. There are very high-resource, intensive ways of getting people, who may not feel that confidence in going into third level, to do those. One of the ways we are looking at is this tertiary pathway where people do a year initially in an ETB and then go into a teacher education qualification. We are exploring how that might work more broadly, so that is something.

As part of the UNESCO work, we are talking to colleagues in the Netherlands. They have a very well-developed second career initiative, which is exactly that. It is a way of attracting men, particularly, who have been working in industry. A lot of the time it is about social motivation. They want to give something back and are coming from engineering backgrounds and all of that. That is something we will look at as part of the workforce development plan.

There are a number of things but we are missing a lot of talent that could really contribute to the teaching profession as well. Of course, the important thing is that people need role models they feel reflect their own experiences. That is really important.

I agree with everything that has just been said. I had written down "white female", when we talked about teachers. In primary school, I had two male and two female teachers and my sons had all female teachers right throughout their primary school.

I want to touch on maths because we talk about the difficulty around STEM. I taught maths at post-primary level. I recall teaching a class one day - they were first or second years - and saying to them in slight frustration that they should have done this in primary school, and asking what they were actually taught in maths at primary school. They said to me that their teacher was no good at maths and they used to show her how to do the maths. The qualification for primary school teachers for maths is on the ordinary level at leaving certificate. Maybe that needs to increase. I am not sure on that; maybe the officials can clarify. If students do not get a good grounding in maths in primary school, they are losing out and it is very difficult for them to catch up in secondary school. We know a lot of students come in with this block against maths. It is like Irish. They have a block against it and say they are no good at it. I said to them that they cannot be no good at maths. There are so many different aspects to maths there will be something they are going to be good at. I often brought children, who came in thinking they were no good at maths, to getting high results. Can that be addressed? How students learn maths in primary and secondary school is having a knock-on impact on what subjects or topics they go on to do later.

The entry is a minimum entry qualification into the initial teacher education degrees. Obviously, the CAO points are quite high. I am sure entrants acquire higher levels of maths than the minimum entry and there are then exit standards that they have to meet. Does Ms Finnegan want to come in on the maths issue in IT?

In the current programme, literacy and numeracy are one of the seven core elements that underpin the accreditation standards. We are only seeing students emerging from those programmes now. The first round of programmes started from 2022, so undergraduates will only be coming out into the system in the next year or so. Postgraduates will be just emerging. We hope that with the students emerging from these newly accredited programmes, because literacy and numeracy are core elements that underpin everything in those programmes and thread through everything, we will see an improvement emerging into the system.
I checked and I do not think higher level maths was required for entry into primary school teaching, at that time. Perhaps it has changed.
Not as an entry criterion.

Therefore, it means someone may be very intelligent and have got high points but not have done higher level maths. You would imagine that person should be able to teach primary school maths, but in this case-----

As Ms Finnegan said, there is a much higher focus on it now, with the introduction of the new standards. One thing the Teachers' Professional Journeys study will look at is to compare teachers who emerged from the initial teacher education programmes before the new standards were introduced with the ones who will emerge when the new standards are introduced. It will see how those teachers feel prepared to teach in the classroom and for the range of things they have to teach. It will be interesting to see whether that will make a difference. The Céim standards will be under review from 2026, again, by the Teaching Council. It is something we are really looking at, evaluating and improving where it needs to be improved.

I listened with great interest to many of the contributions. Some of our line of questioning veered away from what the officials were here to answer. I agree with Senator Tully's point about maths. We brought up concerns about Irish, which matters in the profession. It probably matters in terms of the people we are bringing into the profession, retaining them, or where they go into other areas. I propose, with the agreement of members, that we try to get the NCCA, here in the new year at some point, specifically on maths and Irish, but other subjects as well, if members want to get into it. Maybe we could include the national inspectorate, if there is agreement on that.

Deputy Cummins had an alternative view to what I expressed, but I agree with a huge amount of what she said. The point I was making is that Irish is a subject in a lot of schools at the moment - it is teanga a dó - but we need to have a calibre of Irish. It is an issue that politically is skirted around too often. There is something radically wrong with the way Irish has been going for many decades. It is going to get worse, as a language, unless we teach and learn it to a higher standard and use it in a more day-to-day way than we currently use it.

I also suggest to members, if we can get agreement on this, that the departmental officials with us here today send our committee all interim reports on the longitudinal study, so that we can be kept up to date with developments. Would that be possible? Great.

The other aspect that was mentioned - forgive me, I did not take note of the title of this - was that the officials have a report on diversity in the professions. Is there a report on that? Are you trying to-----
No. It is something that will be part of upcoming work on the workforce development plan.

With the agreement of members, it would be good to look at diversity in teaching and learning. I taught in different schools. At one point, I was struck by the fact I was in a school with a high prevalence of Travellers. It was our daily ambition to keep them in school all the time and get them through the full system. Your heart would jump with joy if you heard they were going on to do their State examinations and were remaining in full-time education.

Your heart, of course, would sink if you heard they dropped out. The one thing that always struck me was that none of the staff were Travellers and for many of us, our life experiences were poles apart from theirs. The books did not resonate with their lifestyles. In the context of Travellers, people of different skin colour or the increased religious diversity in schools that we have now more than ever – that is probably organically addressed but the others are not – we might, if the committee agrees, look at diversity in the profession in the new year. Maybe that is something we can tie in with the NCCA and the inspectorate. Is there agreement in that regard? Does Senator Tully wish to make any additional proposals on maths or anything that we might examine?
We can speak to the NCCA and take it from there.

Very good. I sincerely thank all of our witnesses for being here today. As always, the testimonies and information they provide us with have been useful. We have more work to do in this regard but having the witnesses here today is greatly appreciated. Our meeting now stands adjourned until Thursday, 10 December 2025 at 12.30 p.m., where we will first meet in private session and then proceed to public session. I sincerely thank the committee secretariat, as always, and the technical team who have allowed this meeting team to take place. I really appreciate it.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 11.21 a.m. until 12.30 p.m. on Thursday, 10 December 2025.
